title: Illegal TV streams threatening future of Premier League clubs
text:

Illegal streaming of Premier League football is threatening the future of clubs like Bournemouth and Watford , the boss of the world's biggest sports broadcaster has claimed.

Yousef Al Obaidly, the chief executive of the Qatari-based BeIN media group, warned: “The glorious media rights bubble is about to burst.”

The Premier League sold its broadcast rights from 2019-22 for a record £9.2billion, with a drop in domestic revenue offset by a jump in overseas earnings. BeIN Sports paid £328m for the Middle East rights.

But Al-Obaidly said piracy – such as Premier League matches streamed illegally to pubs and online - is set to drastically devalue sports rights unless action is taken.

(Image: Getty Images)

“Our industry, and rights-holders in particular, are still sleep-walking towards a financial cliff,” he told the Leaders in Sport Summit at Twickenham.

“I’m here to tell you how the endless growth of sports rights is over - the glorious media rights bubble is about to burst. And while most people here think they’ve got their house in order, the truth is that our industry is completely unprepared.

“A rights holder will tell you we want a lot of market correction in the inflation of these rights if this piracy continues. And basically if you look at Premier League clubs, if you take Watford or Bournemouth, the revenue they get today mostly comes from broadcast revenues.

"Broadcast revenues thanks to the deal with Sky in Europe is 88 or 90% of their total revenues so if these rights are sold non-exclusively, the broadcasters will not come and just find that amount of money for the same price. Because it's literally non exclusive.

(Image: Getty Images)

"And that is my response. If we don't do anything about piracy, you will have to have a big big element and the quite a value of reduction in rights.

"Last year BBC research showed that 50% of fans in the UK had accessed Premier League streams through unofficial providers; and a third of fans didn’t even know it was illegal!

“These are commercial revenues that are being shop-lifted every day and shop-lifting is seen as acceptable behaviour by consumers.”

BeIN Sports, which has a £12.16bn portfolio of sports rights, has a particular problem with piracy as the channel is banned in Saudi Arabia as part of an economic boycott.

But the broadcaster's content is widely available through cheap boxes - beoutQ boxes - provided by a Saudi-backed company.
